results.title: Buzz Off
results.brief_description:
This clay-animated story is about respect for others who are different or have different cultures. Overcome by Bees, The Jewel Beetles must flee their home to find a safe place to live. Forced to brave a treacherous river and evade hungry predators, the Jewel Beetles reach the safety of Grasshopper Land. They overhear a debate between two grasshoppers. One grasshopper believes that beetles would bring new perspectives and cultures to Grasshopper Land, while the other grasshopper, fearing change, thinks the beetles don’t belong. Intolerance or acceptance will determine the Jewel Beetles’ fate.
Under the category ‘Primary Animation’, Yarraville West Primary School’s 5/6 Film Team were the Screen It 2011 winners.

results.title: Trip to Mars
results.brief_description: Magical animation details the extraterrestial adventures of hand-drawn harlequin, Koko the clown. Reluctant astronaut Koko inadvertantly launches Mr. Fleischer skyward and the two conclude their supernatural reverie in a ‘taxi-crab’ flung to the rings of Saturn. Koko’s martian odyssey reveals a wealth of unlikely and outlandish natives.

results.title: A Trip to Mars
results.creator_credit: Ashley Miller and Edison Manufacturing Company
results.brief_description: By mixing two power-like substances, a scientist discovers the source of reverse gravity. When he tries this concoction on himself, he is elevated to the planet Mars. This Edison Manufacturing Company production is reported to be the first science-fiction film produced in the United States.

results.title: L'Eclipse du Soleil en Pleine Lune

video_links.name: L'Eclipse du Soleil en Pleine Lune

results.brief_description: An aging astronomer invites students to his castle observatory to observe a solar eclipse. Amid the childish pranks of the novice astronomers and the wondrous vision of the eclipse, George Melies, cinema’s great magician, weaves numerous amusing set pieces. Much to the astronomer’s excitement, the sun and the moon flirt with each other as they come together in an astronomical courtship and the sky explodes in a dance of female stars. On earth, the astronomer falls prey to his cheeky students who rob him of his stately dignity, while the heavens smile down on him from above.

results.title: Le Voyage dans la Lune (A Trip to the Moon)

video_links.name: Le Voyage dans la Lune (A Trip to the Moon)

results.brief_description: Melies’ fantastical vision of life on the moon.

constellations_other.name: Space, sci-fi and cinema fakes
constellations_other.description: Magic lantern slides were used to entertain and educate audiences in home, theatres and universities. While performers told jokes and fairytales, travelling showmen unveiled exotic locations and scientists revealed the latest discoveries.

results.title_for_label: Le Voyage dans la Lune (A Trip to the Moon)
results.description: One of the first Science Fiction films, this Melies’ short humorously proposes what man discovers when he first lands on the moon. Based on the Jules Verne story, George Melies used his extraordinary cinematic illusions to tell this story of the first voyage to the moon. Made in 1902, this was a visionary film that has come to be recognised as a cinematic masterpiece. Among the many comical set pieces is the famous scene in which a rocket ship crash-lands into the eye of the ‘man in the moon’. This whimsical fantasy is also exemplary in its early depiction of the moon and the possible encounters between humans and worlds beyond our imagining, in our exploration of deep space.
description_for_label: One of the first Science Fiction films, this Melies’ short humorously proposes what man discovers when he first lands on the moon. results.title: Reviewing the Australian New Wave panel discussion with David Stratton

video_links.name: Reviewing the Australian New Wave panel discussion with David Stratton

results.brief_description: The 1960s brought on a change in government in Australia, resulting in greater funding towards the arts and Australia’s film industry in particular. In turn, this political change gave rise to what was to be called the ‘Australian New Wave’ in cinema. Celebrated film critic, David Stratton, shares his recollections of this pivotal time with fellow key players: Jan Chapman, Matt Carroll, Paul Cox and Phillip Noyce (via SKYPE). This panel discussion was filmed at ACMI as part of the ‘Margaret and David: 25 years talking movies’ exhibition.

results.title: In conversation with NASA astronaut Rex Walheim
results.brief_description: To top off a decade-long career at NASA, Rex Walheim was in the final shuttle mission for NASA’s 30 year space program. He provides a detailed account of NASA’s space program and space exploration moving forward, as well as the achievements of the past. He also looks at his own path to becoming an astronaut, the experience of space travel and how to do a space walk.

results.title: Signatures of the Soul
results.brief_description: Counter-cultural icon Peter Fonda takes us on a comprehensive journey through the world of tattooing. From early tribal origins and eastern influences, right through to adoption in the mainstream and gradual acceptance as an art form, tattooing has been elevated to both art and an intense form of self-expression.

results.title: Shaun Gladwell: Stereo Sequences interviews
results.creator_credit: David Withers, Jason White, Csilla Csongvay and ACMI
results.brief_description: ‘Shaun Gladwell: Stereo Sequences’ is the first in the ‘New Horizons’ series of ACMI commissions. Gladwell uses filmic devices such as slow-motion and long pans to capture both tightly choreographed and improvised performances by breakdancers, skateboarders and BMX bike riders in a combination of rural and city settings. The resulting works, which he describes as “performative landscapes” are both rhythmic and poetic - distorting speed, gravity, space and time; exploring visual and spatial paradoxes. He discusses his art practice and his collaboration with other performers and artists for this exhibition. Other interviews include; Sarah Tutton (ACMI curator), Josh Raymond (Gladwell producer) Vivienne Wong (Australian Ballet) and Lamaroc (street dancer).

results.title: Jeff Lindsay in conversation with Sue Turnball: Dark Tales, Serial Archetypes
results.creator_credit: David Meagher, Csilla Csongvay and ACMI

video_links.name: Jeff Lindsay in conversation with Sue Turnball: Dark Tales, Serial Archetypes

results.brief_description:
Jeff Lindsay, author and creator of our favourite serial killer ‘Dexter’, is joined in conversation with Professor Sue Turnbull, as they explore the renaissance of macabre fairytales in popular culture.

Jeff Lindsay and Sue Turnbull touched on many of the themes covered in the ‘Fairytales Re-imagined’ symposium, providing a fascinatingly insightful discussion centred around the development of fairy tale motifs in popular culture.
